      <title>Ireland's border country: walking the line and in love with the landscape</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/feb/18/walking-ireland-northern-ireland-border-country-garrett-carr-mountains-standing-stones</link>
      <description><p>Since the Brexit referendum, the Irish border has again become a source of tension but on the ground it remains a fascinating wilderness of low mountains and fantastic hiking country</p><p>Today I’m hiking from Thur Mountain to the Cavan Burren along lanes and among prehistoric relics. This is north-west Ireland, not far from the sea but far enough for me to call it midlands. My route goes from Co Leitrim into Co Cavan, staying close to the border with Northern Ireland. For so long associated with violence and up against the appeal of the west coast, Ireland’s borderland has been ignored by travellers. Yet its history is fascinating and there are many beautiful stretches. Word is starting to get out, but this still feels like Ireland’s undiscovered region.</p><p>I spent last night in a B&amp;B in Glenfarne, a thinly spread community of farms and homes. <a href="http://www.clancysofglenfarne.com/accommodation/">Clancy’s</a> (doubles from €89 B&amp;B, walking packages available) appears to be the area’s heart, a string of businesses along the roadside, under one roof. It’s a B&amp;B, a cafe, a shop and a post office.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/feb/18/walking-ireland-northern-ireland-border-country-garrett-carr-mountains-standing-stones">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>A role in The Mercy – alongside Colin Firth and Rachel Weisz – has put the charming but faded seaside town in the spotlight</p><p>Everybody admires Teignmouth (pronounced “Tin-muth”). The problem is, most people don’t know they have been there, as inter-city trains whizz by without stopping, and if you blink you miss the station.       <description><p>Chinese new year signals major travel across the country, and railways are at the heart of many journeys. Author and BBC journalist Michael Bristow knows China well – and the insight time on board offers</p><ul><li><strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/feb/16/how-to-book-travel-high-speed-train-china-shanghai-beijing-shenzhen">How to travel by high-speed train around China</a></strong></li></ul><p>Chinese people will make nearly 400 million train trips over Chinese new year (16 February this year). Migrant workers will leave the cities and head back to the countryside to see their children; students will travel home for the long winter holiday; elderly parents will visit their grown-up children.</p><p>The mass arrival of cars and planes has changed the nature of travel in China but the railways remain the country’s most important form of transport. However, trains do not just get you from A to B: in China, these often long journeys give travellers a snapshot of ordinary life, a sense of where they are.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/feb/16/china-by-train-tracks-tales-chinese-new-year">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/feb/16/how-to-book-travel-high-speed-train-china-shanghai-beijing-shenzhen</link>
      <description><p>China’s rail network is a fast-paced wonder that makes exploring this huge country – including Beijing, Shanghai and Shenzhen – much easier<br>• <strong><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/feb/16/china-by-train-tracks-tales-chinese-new-year">China by train: tracks, tales and a snapshot of daily life</a></strong></p><p>Friday is Chinese new year and also the beginning of the spring festival, a national holiday in China (known as Chun Jie), which heralds what has been called the largest human migration in the world, with millions of people making journeys home for the holidays. China’s growing high-speed rail network – which is the longest in the world, too – carries a significant transport burden, with almost 60% of the population using it over a three-week-plus period.</p><p>It’s not just locals who can take advantage of the vastly improved journey times that the network offers: tourists too can use high-speed trains to visit more of China – and a whole lot faster. Many high-speed rail journeys are, ultimately, quicker than flying.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/feb/16/how-to-book-travel-high-speed-train-china-shanghai-beijing-shenzhen">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Tasting Buenos Aires: food tours, street art and tango – a local’s guide to the city</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/feb/12/buenos-aires-locals-guide-argentina-cafes-bars-arts</link>
      <description><p>With budget airline Norwegian launching direct flights to Buenos Aires this week, local experts show our writer around their city, and also chip in with a few tips of their own<br></p><ul><li><strong>Share your tips on the city in the comments below</strong></li></ul><p>I’m not usually one for guided tours, but with precious little time and so much to see in this enormous, fascinating city, I signed up for three with <a href="https://www.travellocal.com/countries/argentina">TravelLocal</a>. My first guide, Patricia, had that gift of making history come alive: as we strolled down Avenida Corrientes (the “Broadway of BA”), she described how waves of Europeans immigrants have influenced the culture of Argentina, and its cuisine. On the way, we stopped at <a href="http://www.pizzeriaguerrin.com/">Pizzeria Güerrin</a>, opened by a Genoese family in 1932 and buzzing at lunchtime with workers standing at tables wolfing down slices of pizza dripping with mozzarella (no thin crusts here – Argentinian pizzas are rated by how much bubbly white cheese the crusty base can withstand). For dessert we moved onto <a href="http://www.heladeriacadore.com.ar/">Heladeria Cadore</a>, originally founded in northern Italy in the 19th century. The family moved to BA and opened the ice-cream parlour in 1957. New flavours are added all the time but the <em>dulce de leche</em> and lime are perennial classics.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/feb/12/buenos-aires-locals-guide-argentina-cafes-bars-arts">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>A reopened secret wartime bunker that was used by Churchill and staffed by WRNS and WAAF personnel offers an educational day out – and the cheapest cup of tea in the land</p><ul><li><strong>Share your tips for other great family attractions in Liverpool in the comments</strong><br></li></ul><p>With Gary Oldman Oscar nominated for his performance as Winston Churchill in <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2017/sep/13/darkest-hour-review-gary-oldman-toronto-film-festival-tiff">Darkest Hour</a>, the UK’s war-time leader is in focus. Churchill was a frequent visitor to Western Approaches, the secret bunker under Liverpool that has been reopened by Chester-based social enterprise group Big Heritage. It was the nerve centre to coordinate the Battle of the Atlantic and staffed mainly by Women’s Royal Naval Service (WRNS) and Women’s Auxiliary Air Force, (WAAFs). The bunker is in the basement of an office building in Moorfields, Liverpool’s business quarter, but is just five minutes from Pier Head and the waterfront. Combine it with a visit to the Terracotta Warriors <a href="http://www.liverpoolmuseums.org.uk/wml/exhibitions/terracotta-warriors/index.aspx">at the World Museum</a>, opening on 9 February, for a thoroughly educational day out.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/feb/08/western-approaches-liverpool-war-museum-review-family-day-trips">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/jan/25/best-places-to-visit-florida-historic-sights-beaches-readers-tips</link>
      <description><p>It’s not all showy spectacle, queues, rides and golf in the Sunshine State: historic sites, glorious gardens, quiet beaches and Biff’s burger joint also feature</p><p>Near the small town of Estero, about 12 miles from Cape Coral, is beautiful <a href="https://www.floridastateparks.org/park/Koreshan">Koreshan state park</a>, which up until the early 1960s was the last home of a 19th-century cult, the Koreshan Unity. They believed the Earth was hollow, set up a community here in 1894, called New Jerusalem and produced their own newspaper. They also were the first to provide the surrounding community with electricity. The last follower of the cult, a woman who had fled Nazi persecution in Germany called Hedwig Michel, ceded the grounds to Florida in 1961. The park is beautifully maintained and staffed by knowledgeable volunteers. Visitors can walk around the landscaped site and see many of the buildings used by the community. It’s fascinating, peaceful and very strange – quite unlike the well-known bits of Florida. You pay $5 a car for parking. Activities such as kayaking and camping are available in the park and there are wildlife and running trails, too.<br><strong>ArchivistS</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2018/jan/25/best-places-to-visit-florida-historic-sights-beaches-readers-tips">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Readers’ picks of weird wonders include fun times in a Transylvanian salt mine, getting soaked in an Austrian castle and the world’s largest pig museum<br><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/series/readers-travel-tips">Send us a tip for the chance to win a £200 hotel voucher</a></p><p>For a surreal experience, look no further than the Salina Turda salt mine.       <title>The most rock'n'roll hotel in the world? Los Angeles' Chateau Marmont</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2011/sep/28/rock-n-roll-hotels-chateau-marmont</link>
      <description>The author of Rock &amp; Roll Hotels, a new guidebook that  lifts the lid on what rock stars get up to after the after-party, on the most rock'n'roll hotel of them all, Chateau Marmont in Hollywood<p>A night at the infamous Chateau Marmont, which rises above the Sunset Strip like a leviathan of gothic glamour, is part of the quintessential Hollywood experience. Actors, musicians, writers and the affluent elite have all been known to hole up in this legendary paparazzi-free zone in order to revel in romantic rebellion. Indeed, many guests even became habitués in order to blaze a trail with reckless abandon seven days a week.</p><p>The tales from the Chateau have become so legendary that anyone with even a passing interest in rock'n'roll – or any facet of the entertainment industry for that matter – will have heard a Hollywood story related to Chateau Marmont. If you think you haven't, maybe this by no means comprehensive list will jog your memory. <strong>James Dean</strong> hopped through a window to audition for Rebel Without a Cause; <strong>Judy Garland</strong> sang by the grand piano in the lobby; Canyon cowboy <strong>Gram Parsons</strong> lived here for a short time; Blues Brother <strong>John Belushi </strong>overdosed in bungalow number three; <strong>Led Zeppelin</strong> drove their Harley Davidsons into the hotel lobby; <strong>The Doors' Jim Morrison</strong> dangled precariously from his window; esteemed record producer <strong>Rick Rubin</strong> lived here for nine months in the 1990s after relocating from New York; <strong>John Frusciante</strong>, guitarist with Red Hot Chili Peppers, took up residence here in 1996, only to descend into a drugs hell that nearly claimed his life; <strong>Anthony Kiedis</strong>, also of Chili Peppers, recorded his vocals for By the Way in his room at the hotel; <strong>Ville Valo</strong> of Finnish rock band HIM, recorded his vocals for the track Song Or Suicide here; <strong>Lindsay Lohan</strong> checked in following her arrest for drink driving in 2007; <strong>Lily Allen</strong> wrote the song Fuck You while at the hotel; <strong>Heath Ledger</strong> partied here the week before he died … Deep breath.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2011/sep/28/rock-n-roll-hotels-chateau-marmont">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>In Grandpa’s footsteps on the shores of Carlingford Lough, Ireland</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2017/oct/29/carlingford-lough-ferry-northern-ireland-grandpa</link>
      <description><p>Hannah Louise Summers uses a new ferry service – a lake crossing on which her grandfather once worked – to explore both sides of Carlingford Lough, which straddles the Irish border</p><p>Every school holiday was the same. For hours we’d trundle south from Belfast in my grandpa’s battered blue minibus – a journey dotted with punctures, Werther’s Originals and mugs of tea. We’d cross the border, stop for a loaf of bread and a scratchcard, and finally pull into Omeath, the small village on Carlingford Lough where my grandpa grew up.</p><p>Here, on a hill overlooking the water, granny and grandpa had a pea-green static caravan. Trapped in the claustrophobic web of its net curtains, I’d make the most of my holiday, playing shop with anyone who’d pop in. Sometimes I’d wander down to the shore, lose my hard-hustled coppers to a tiny room of slot machines, or throw some pebbles in the lough – the lough where Grandpa first wooed Granny when she was here on her holidays; the lough where Grandpa worked as a ferryman.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2017/oct/29/carlingford-lough-ferry-northern-ireland-grandpa">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Holiday guide to Puglia, southern Italy: the best towns, restaurants and hotels</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/jul/04/puglia-guide-italy-hotels-bari-brindisi-foggia-salento</link>
      <description><p>Beyond Puglia’s crowded hotspots, there are nature reserves, dramatic caves, medieval quarters and several hundred miles of coastline to enjoy, not to mention the region’s star attraction: fantastic food </p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/jul/02/puglia-readers-travel-tips"><strong>Readers share their Puglia travel tips</strong></a><br></li></ul><p>Poor Puglia. For centuries rampaging armies used this heel of Italy as a convenient motorway en route to richer pickings further afield. Nowadays, tourists treat a large part of the region in much the same way – barely touching the ground at Brindisi or Bari before speeding south to newly trendy Salento, Puglia’s far southern tip (which we’ve covered in <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/travel/2014/apr/25/italy-puglia-salento-region">a separate guide</a>).</p><p>What they’re missing as they charge pell-mell for Lecce, Gallipoli et al is a profusion of medieval hilltop towns, olive groves, a coastline peppered with interesting towns, more olive groves, restaurant menus stuffed with local speciality dishes, two national parks, vineyards, yet more olive groves, and enough <em>castelli</em>, <em>cattedrali</em> and <em>palazzi</em> to keep even the most demanding of history buffs content. Oh, and Europe’s largest colony of pink flamingos.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2015/jul/04/puglia-guide-italy-hotels-bari-brindisi-foggia-salento">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description>Spain’s capital is awash with tapas bars but how do you find the good ones amid the sea of tourist-traps? Madrid-based food writer <a href=" http://www.madridchow.com/" title="">James Blick</a> tracks down 10 of the best, from classic bodegas to slick new dining spaces run by young chefs<p>Were Woody Allen to set one of his romantic European whimsies in Madrid, Casa Gonzalez – with its picture-perfect yesteryear facade, smartly tiled interior and moreish hoard of conserves, cheese and charcuterie – would be a shoo-in for the romantic Spanish bar scene. What’s more, the good-humoured and well-moustached owner Paco (whose grandfather founded the place in 1931) keeps a knockout cellar at this wine bar-slash-deli. Nab a table near the big bay window, load it with <em>jamón ibérico de bellota</em> (acorn-fed Iberian ham, €10.10), cured manchego cheese (€6), and a spicy bottle of red and watch the light fade over the cobblestones outside – a most cinematic start to any tapas crawl.<br>• <em>Calle León 12, +34 914 295 618, </em><a href="http://www.casagonzalez.es/"><em>casagonzalez.es</em></a><em>. Open everyday, Mon-Thur 9.30am-midnight, Fri and Sat 9.30am-1am, Sun 11am-6pm</em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2014/aug/13/madrid-tapas-bars-top-10">Continue reading...</a></description>
